title: 109_s3880
content: The "Animal Enterprise Terrorism Act" is cited as the short title. Section 43 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include economic damage to animal enterprises and threats of death and serious bodily injury to associated persons. The "Animal Enterprise Terrorism Act" prohibits using interstate commerce to damage or interfere with animal enterprises, including causing property damage or instilling fear of harm to individuals associated with the enterprise. The "Animal Enterprise Terrorism Act" prohibits conduct involving threats, vandalism, property damage, trespass, harassment, or intimidation towards animal enterprises. Penalties include fines or imprisonment up to 5 years for offenses causing economic damage exceeding $10,000. The penalties for offenses under the "Animal Enterprise Terrorism Act" vary based on the severity of the offense. This includes fines, imprisonment up to 20 years, or life imprisonment if the offense results in death. An order of restitution under the Animal Enterprise Terrorism Act may include costs for repeating interrupted experimentation, loss of food production, and other economic damages. The term 'animal enterprise' refers to commercial or academic ventures involving animals or animal products. The term 'course of conduct' refers to a pattern of behavior with a continuous purpose. 'Economic damage' includes costs related to property damage, loss of profits, and increased expenses resulting from threats or acts against a person or entity connected to production, agriculture, education, research, or testing, zoos, circuses, fairs, or similar events. The term 'serious bodily injury' refers to injuries posing a substantial risk of death, extreme physical pain, protracted and obvious disfigurement, or protracted loss or impairment of bodily function. 'Substantial bodily injury' includes deep cuts, serious burns, fractured bones, or torn body parts. The term 'serious bodily injury' includes injuries such as fractured or dislocated bones, significant physical pain, illness, short-term loss of bodily function, or any other significant injury to the body. This section does not prohibit expressive conduct protected by the First Amendment or create new remedies for interference with free speech or free exercise clauses. The item relating to section 43 in the table of sections at the beginning of chapter 3 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to read as follows: interference; or ``(3) to provide exclusive criminal penalties or civil remedies with respect to the conduct prohibited by this action, or to preempt State or local laws that may provide such penalties or remedies.''. The item relating to section 43 in title 18, United States Code, is amended to address force, violence, and threats involving animal enterprises.
